RelatedSentence: The U.S. Department of Justice has shuttered the Blackshades malware operation , which sold potentially pernicious software that was installed on as many as 500,000 computers worldwide .
The U.S. Department of Justice has shuttered the Blackshades malware operation , which sold potentially pernicious software that was installed on as many as 500,000 computers worldwide .

The U.S. Attorney 's Office for the Southern District of New York arrested three alleged key members of the Blackshades organization , as well as two individuals in the New York area who the DOJ said used the software to break into hundreds of computers , it announced Monday .
The DOJ coordinated efforts with law enforcement agencies across 19 countries to make the arrests .
Authorities arrested 97 people globally .
The DOJ also disabled the Blackshades Web domain , where the invasive software was sold .

A0: Preet Bharara , U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York
RelatedSentence: I think the days when people thought they could very simply and anonymously buy malware to invade other people 's privacy and steal their property are over , said Preet Bharara , U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York , at a press conference announcing the arrests .

Blackshades allegedly sold a remote access tool , or RAT , which could capture information on a user 's computer , including photographs , documents and passwords to access online accounts .
Blackshades allegedly sold a remote access tool , or RAT , which could capture information on a user 's computer , including photographs , documents and passwords to access online accounts .
It could record every keystroke made on a user 's keyboard , which could be used to steal credit card numbers and other sensitive information .
It could record every keystroke made on a user 's keyboard , which could be used to steal credit card numbers and other sensitive information .
RAT software was purchased by users in more than 100 countries and infected more than 500,000 computers , the DOJ estimated .
The software was most often surreptitiously installed on a user 's computer when they clicked on a Web address link that would download and install the software .
The software was most often surreptitiously installed on a user 's computer when they clicked on a Web address link that would download and install the software .
Once on a user 's computer , the software could propagate itself to other computers by sending messages to people in the computer 's address book .
The DOJ had already arrested the suspected creators of Blackshades , Michael Hogue , aka xVisceral , and Alec Yucel .
Hogue was arrested in Arizona in June 2012 , subsequently pled guilty in January 2013 and has been cooperating with the government investigation , the DOJ said .
He and Yucel have been charged with multiple counts of computer hacking , with each count carrying a maximum penalty of up to 10 years in prison .
Brendan Johnston , a former Blackshades employee who allegedly helped sell RAT and provided technical assistance , has also been arrested .
